conclusion: Objects labeled A and B are lifted and moved through the air to the locations marked by objects A, B, C, and D.
When objects A and B are dropped, they come into contact with objects A, B, C, and D due to gravity.
Objects A and B cover the area where objects C and D are located.
The weight and placement of objects A and B cause the objects beneath (C, D) to be covered and possibly compressed.
Objects A and B are now resting on the surface, covering where objects C and D were positioned.
The fabrics draped over the objects are visibly distorted, indicating the presence of the objects beneath.
When objects A and B are placed at the locations of C and D, they cover and interact with objects A, B, C, and D, creating a draped effect.
The objects will be covered and compressed by the weight of objects A and B, resulting in a draped fabric appearance as seen in the images.
